repnme.cdata!:
Cote d'Ivoire - Emergency Urban
            Infrastructure Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Emergency Urban Infrastructure
            Project in Cote d'Ivoire received a highly satisfactory
            outcome with substantial risk to development outcome. Both
            the Bank and the Borrowers performance was satisfactory.
            The Project Development Objective was changed to capture the
            expanded project scope to include additional cities so as to
            support the general development of the country. The revised
            PDO was to increase access and improve the quality of urban
            infrastructure facilities and services in Abidjan, Bouake,
            and other selected cities. The achievement of this objective
            would support the Governmetn of Cote d'Ivoire
            (GoCI's) efforts to demonstrate concrete improvements
            in the lives of its citizens, a critical step for sustaining
            social and political stability in the country. This revised
            PDO was part of the first restructuring of this project
            which also included an extension of the closing date by one
            year. The second restructuring of the project extended the
            closing date another six months for a total of 18 months due
            to the suspension during the post-election crisis.
            Additional financing was awarded to components one through
            four. The purposes for each are as follows: Component 1: (i)
            the protection of ground water resources of the North Zone
            in Adjame and Nord Riviera in Cocody, and establishment of a
            network for ground water monitoring in Bonoua; (ii) the
            reinforcement of water supply in Abidjan through
            construction of boreholes in Anyama and extension of water
            distribution facilities; (iii) reinforcement and
            rehabilitation of water production and distribution
            facilities in Bouake and other selected cities, and power
            supply improvement to the water production facilities in
            Bouake; and (iv) implementation of a program to increase
            water supply in selected cities. Component 2: The Additional
            Financing would support treatment of more wastewater and
            contribute to restoration of the deteriorated environmental
            condition of the Abidjan lagoon and low-lying areas of the
            hydrological basin of Gourou. Particular focus will be given
            to water drainage under the Indenie and Cocody bays, which
            constitutes a serious health hazard for the population
            around the Gourou basin. Component 3: The funds would be
            used for (i) improvement of the solid waste collection
            infrastructure, including rehabilitation, construction and
            equipment of grouping and triage centers, and (ii)
            improvement of working conditions of waste workers. The
            Additional Funds would finance works in the rehabilitation
            of mass transit routes in Abidjan and other selected cities,
            including rehabilitation of dilapidated road segments and
            construction of urban roads and bridges. Around Abidjan, the
            works would contribute to restoring more reliable public
            transportation services in the seriously disadvantaged
            municipalities of Abobo, Yopougon, and Cocody that were no
            longer served by public transportation due to road
            degradation. The following lessons were learned: (1)
            Emergency Projects benefit from simple implementation
            arrangements and having the Task Team Leader (TTL)
            in-country. (2) Keeping cities clean requires continuous
            efforts and not just a single campaign. (3) Keep citizens
            engaged in further municipal reforms and the on-going
            decentralization program. (4) Conduct field surveys to
            establish baseline data and to raise the monitoring and
            evaluation capacity in the country. (5) Improving the
            management and benefits of standpipes. (6) Addressing the
            high costs of sewerage connections. (7) Strengthen
            cooperation among government staff.

repnme.cdata!:
Cote d'Ivoire - Emergency Urban
            Infrastructure Project : resettlement plan

abstracts.cdata!:
This report is the Framework
            Environmental Management and Social (CGES) Project Emergency
            Urban Infrastructure (PUIUR). This program aims to assist
            the Ivorian government to upgrade access and quality of
            infrastructure and urban services in two (2) major cities,
            namely Abidjan and Bouake. Achieving this goal will support
            the efforts of the government of Cote d'Ivoire to
            improve in a visible and tangible the lives of its citizens,
            to maintain political and social stability and economic
            recovery of the country. The grant will help finance the
            costs associated with the following activities: (i) urban
            water supply; (ii) urban sanitation (sewerage); (iii) solid
            waste management; (iv) urban roads rehabilitation; and (v)
            municipal contracts. The project is also intended, at the
            same time, to carry out urban and financial audits of 10
            cities in the country in order to jumpstart management
            improvement and needs assessment in these cities. The
            operations of PUIUR activities consist of rehabilitation of
            infrastructure (construction and rehabilitation works of
            art, books evacuation of solid waste and liquid waste,
            water, roads, sanitation, roads school urban) in both cities
            (Abidjan and Bouake). The operations and techniques of work
            on these sites are well known so as to minimize their impact
            on individuals and their property. However, negative impacts
            could be caused by the activities of PUIUR on these three
            levels: loss of land, acquisition of land for carrying out
            the arrangements of the crossroads and bridges, installation
            of a temporary site during the work and eventual
            resettlement of displaced persons; loss of assets
            (infrastructure, equipment, means of production), demolition
            of homes, closing workshops, crops, schools and so on; loss
            of resources, loss of income for those engaged in informal
            employment etc.

Cote d'Ivoire - Emergency

            Plan d'action de reinstallation
